criteria: Connection Between Philosophers' Ideas and Democratic Revolutions
Comparison of Philosophers' Effects on Revolutions
descriptions: The student demonstrates no understanding of the major ideas of the philosophers listed (Locke, Montesquieu, Rousseau, Smith).
The student demonstrates a very limited understanding of the major ideas of one or more of the philosophers, with significant inaccuracies.
The student demonstrates a basic understanding of the major ideas of one or two of the philosophers, but with some inaccuracies or omissions.
The student demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of the major ideas of most of the philosophers, with minor inaccuracies or omissions.
The student demonstrates a strong understanding of the major ideas of all the philosophers, with only minor omissions.
The student demonstrates a comprehensive and nuanced understanding of the major ideas of all the philosophers, including their complexities and nuances.
The student fails to make any connection between the philosophers' ideas and the democratic revolutions.
The student makes a weak or inaccurate connection between the philosophers' ideas and one of the democratic revolutions.
The student makes a basic connection between the philosophers' ideas and one or two of the democratic revolutions, but with limited detail.
The student connects the philosophers' ideas to several of the democratic revolutions, explaining the influence with some accuracy.
The student clearly connects the philosophers' ideas to all the democratic revolutions, explaining the influence with accuracy and relevant detail.

The student provides insightful and nuanced connections between the philosophers' ideas and the democratic revolutions, demonstrating a deep understanding of the cause-and-effect relationships and historical context.
The student does not compare the effects of the philosophers on the revolutions.
The student offers a minimal or inaccurate comparison of the effects of the philosophers on the revolutions.
The student provides a limited comparison, identifying one or two similarities or differences.
The student compares the effects of the philosophers, identifying several similarities and differences with reasonable accuracy.
The student offers a thorough comparison of the effects of the philosophers, identifying multiple similarities and differences with supporting details and examples.

The student provides a sophisticated and insightful comparison of the effects of the philosophers, analyzing the nuances and complexities of their influence on the revolutions with exceptional clarity.
